page.title: 06BRADFORD TRANSPORT INT'CHGE
page.content: Bradford's public transport history is one of rivalry & uncontrolled growth which resulted in two unconnected railway termini and terminal nodes for routes at various points near the City centre. On an {8\ acre site, }within 100m of the City Hall, a functional {"Interchange" was opened in 1977 }for all public transport services as well as some private vehicles. Road access is direct from the city's inner ring road. A pedestrian concourse forms the spine of the complex with escalators up to six island platforms of the {bus {station }which handles over 250 bus movements an hour at peak times. There is also access to {"Exchange" Railway {station }on the eastern edge of the site. The interchange is a landmark because of its{unique glass roof}which covers the whole site like a giant wavy lilo.
